Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.plugins.devs

DEVS simulation plug-ins for a cyber-physical component model based on BCM.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AtomicSimulatorPluginI
    The interface AtomicSimulatorPluginI declares the most generic services of the DEVS atomic simulator plug-in.
    CoordinatorPluginFactoryI
    The interface CoordinatorPluginFactoryI declares the methods to be implemented by a coordinator plug-in factory to create a coordinator plug-in.
    CoordinatorPluginI
    The interface CoordinatorPluginI declares the methods that a coordinator plug-in must implement.
    RTAtomicSimulatorPluginI
    The interface RTAtomicSimulatorPluginI declares elements required in an atomic simulator plug-in for real time simulations.
    RTAtomicSimulatorPluginI.EventFactoryFI
    The functional interface EventFactoryFI allows to create event factories for DEVS simulations in BCMCyPhy.
    RTCoordinatorPluginI
    The interface RTCoordinatorPluginI defines the methods to be provided by a real time coordinator pluyg-in.
    RTSimulatorPluginI
    The interface RTSimulatorPluginI;defines the methods to be provided by a real time simulator plug-in.
    SimulatorPluginI
    The interface SimulatorPluginI declares the core services of the DEVS simulator plug-in.
    SupervisorPluginI
    The interface SupervisorPluginI declares the core services of the DEVS simulation supervisor plug-in.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractSimulatorPlugin
    The abstract class AbstractSimulatorPlugin implements the core simulation methods (DEVS protocol and management) as a BCM plug-in.
    AtomicSimulatorPlugin
    The class AtomicSimulatorPlugin implements the behaviours required by a component that holds an atomic simulation model; it acts mostly as a facade for the simulation engine and model that it is holding, passing them most of the calls sometimes with adaptations (glue) to account for the fact that communication among simulation engines and models may pass through component connections.
    CoordinatorPlugin
    The class CoordinatorPlugin implements a BCM plug-in for the coordination role in DEVS simulations.
    RTAtomicSimulatorPlugin
    The class RTAtomicSimulatorPlugin extends an atomic simulator plug-in with the methods required by a real time atomic simulator plug-in.
    RTCoordinatorPlugin
    The class RTCoordinatorPlugin implements the real time coordinator plug-in used to perform real time simulation over BCM components.
    StandardCoordinatorPluginFactory
    The class StandardCoordinatorPluginFactory defines a standard coordinator plug-in factory which creates the coordinator plug-in from a given class; if no class is given, the standard on is used.
    SupervisorPlugin
    The class SupervisorPlugin implements the role of DEVS simulation supervision for BCM components as a plug-in.

Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.plugins.devs Description

DEVS simulation plug-ins for a cyber-physical component model based on BCM.

Licence

Copyright Jacques Malenfant, Sorbonne Universite.

Jacques.Malenfant@lip6.fr

This software is a computer program whose purpose is to provide an extension of the BCM component model that aims to define a components tailored for cyber-physical control systems (CPCS) for Java.

This software is governed by the CeCILL-C license under French law and abiding by the rules of distribution of free software. You can use, modify and/ or redistribute the software under the terms of the CeCILL-C license as circulated by CEA, CNRS and INRIA at the following URL http://www.cecill.info.

As a counterpart to the access to the source code and rights to copy, modify and redistribute granted by the license, users are provided only with a limited warranty and the software's author, the holder of the economic rights, and the successive licensors have only limited liability.

In this respect, the user's attention is drawn to the risks associated with loading, using, modifying and/or developing or reproducing the software by the user in light of its specific status of free software, that may mean that it is complicated to manipulate, and that also therefore means that it is reserved for developers and experienced professionals having in-depth computer knowledge. Users are therefore encouraged to load and test the software's suitability as regards their requirements in conditions enabling the security of their systems and/or data to be ensured and, more generally, to use and operate it in the same conditions as regards security.

The fact that you are presently reading this means that you have had knowledge of the CeCILL-C license and that you accept its terms.

This package defines three different plug-ins related to the integration of DEVS simulation models into BCM components. DEVS is a simulation standard allowing to define modular models that are either atomic or coupled. Atomic models are used to define user-specific models while coupled models are used to compose models to create progressively full-fledged simulators for whole systems.

The basic idea behind integrating simulation models into components is to allow the users to specify the behaviour of the component using models that are executable. These models can be used to validate the design of a cyber-physical system that will be constructed as a component assembly. In this first phase, standalone model-in-the-loop simulators can provide a theoretical validation. During the development process, software-in-the-loop simulators can be coupled with the software developed in components to debug and test it, until the full system is developed and then its software can be verified and validated. At deployment, hardware-in-the-loop simulators can be used for final verification and validation of the full cyber-physical system in its target physical environment.

The three plug-ins defined in this package correspond to three roles that components can play in a simulation:

  1. atomic simulator, that executes both atomic models or coupled models seen as atomic (thanks to the closure over composition property of DEVS models) that reside within one component;
  2. coordinator, that executes coupled models which amounts to coordinating the submodels;
  3. supervisor, that manages simulations which amounts first to create and interconnect simulation architectures and then to manage simulation runs by providing simulation run parameters, execute runs and then retrieve simulation reports to analyse their results.
